user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_pred:
```c
static int lfs_fs_pred(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_block_t pair[2], lfs_mdir_t *pdir) {
    // iterate over all directory directory entries
    pdir->tail[0] = 0;
    pdir->tail[1] = 1;
    struct lfs_tortoise_t tortoise = {
        .pair = {LFS_BLOCK_NULL, LFS_BLOCK_NULL},
        .i = 1,
        .period = 1,
    };
    int err = LFS_ERR_OK;
    while (!lfs_pair_isnull(pdir->tail)) {
        err = lfs_tortoise_detectcycles(pdir, &tortoise);
        if (err < 0) {
            return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
        }

        if (lfs_pair_cmp(pdir->tail, pair) == 0) {
            return 0;
        }

        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, pdir, pdir->tail);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return LFS_ERR_NOENT;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_fs_pred:
static inline bool lfs_pair_isnull(const lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    return pair[0] == LFS_BLOCK_NULL || pair[1] == LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
}
...
static int lfs_tortoise_detectcycles(
    const lfs_mdir_t *dir, struct lfs_tortoise_t *tortoise) {
    // detect cycles with Brent's algorithm
    if (lfs_pair_issync(dir->tail, tortoise->pair)) {
        LFS_WARN("Cycle detected in tail list");
        return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
    }
    if (tortoise->i == tortoise->period) {
        tortoise->pair[0] = dir->tail[0];
        tortoise->pair[1] = dir->tail[1];
        tortoise->i = 0;
        tortoise->period *= 2;
    }
    tortoise->i += 1;

    return LFS_ERR_OK;
}
...
static inline int lfs_pair_cmp(
        const lfs_block_t paira[2],
        const lfs_block_t pairb[2]) {
    return !(paira[0] == pairb[0] || paira[1] == pairb[1] ||
             paira[0] == pairb[1] || paira[1] == pairb[0]);
}
...
static int lfs_dir_fetch(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_mdir_t *dir, const lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    // note, mask=-1, tag=-1 can never match a tag since this
    // pattern has the invalid bit set
    return (int)lfs_dir_fetchmatch(lfs, dir, pair,
            (lfs_tag_t)-1, (lfs_tag_t)-1, NULL, NULL, NULL);
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pdir->tail[0] = 0;
    pdir->tail[1] = 1;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The two assignments initialize pdir->tail immediately before the while loop and are executed; they affect the loop condition (!lfs_pair_isnull(pdir->tail)) and are therefore reachable. With the expected sentinel value for LFS_BLOCK_NULL (a distinct invalid block value, e.g. -1/0xFFFFFFFF in littlefs), the loop body can be entered and the assignments are not dead/unreachable. (Only if LFS_BLOCK_NULL were defined as 0 or 1 would the loop body become unreachable due to these initializations, but that is not the case in the intended implementation.)
